Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports the research of Professors Armstrong and Finn at the College of William and Mary. The group conducts nuclear physics experiments using the polarized electron beam available at the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility. These experiments utilize the tiny violation of "mirror symmetry" in electron scattering, which occurs due to the presence of the weak neutral-current interaction, an otherwise unnoticeable contribution to the scattering process. This "parity-violation" technique is being used to probe the quark structure of protons and neutrons, to study the distribution of neutrons in a heavy nucleus (which has important implications for understanding neutron stars), and to search for possible new forces or new particles beyond those in the Standard Model of particle physics.

The grant supports a postdoctoral fellow and four graduate students. Substantial involvement of undergraduate students is also anticipated through senior research projects and the REU site program at William and Mary.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proton is known to contain three quarks, always present within, which are held together via the strong force.  However, the proton's internal structure is more rich and complicated, and includes a "sea" of additional quark-antiquark pairs, that are continuously created and then annihilated. Physicists had speculated that this sea of quarks might contribute to some of the basic properties of the proton, including its distribution of electric charge and its magnetic properties. This project involved several experiments which made highly precise measurements of the neutral-current weak interaction of intense beams of energetic electrons when scattered from protons. This weak interaction of the electron with the proton was used to determine the contribution of strange "sea" quarks to the proton's electric and magnetic properties. These contributions were found to be very small, at most a few percent, and consistent with zero, which has enabled us to rule out a number of theories that had predicted more substantial effects.

Weak interaction electron scattering measurements were also made using a 208Pb target, which allowed us to measure the average radius of the neutron distribution in this nucleus. This provided the first unambiguous observation of the expected "neutron skin" of a heavy nucleus (the neutron distribution extends further out from the nuclear center than do the protons). This has important implications for our understanding of neutron-rich matter, including neutron stars.  

In addition, a new experiment was developed, and data-taking begun, which will use a similar technique to measure, for the first time, the proton's weak charge. This will provide a stringent test of the Standard Model of particle physics, and has the potential to discover indirect evidence for certain kinds of "new physics" (new particles or new forces). 

Eight graduate students participated in this project, two of whom have completed their PhDs; a total of seven PhD theses are expected from this project, under the supervision of the prinicpal investigator. Five undergraduate students also did research within the project. A postdoctoral researcher also participated, partially supported from this grant, and he has now secured a permanent research scientist position.

The results have been published in nine papers in the scientific literature, presented at a number of conferences and meetings, with several more papers still in preparation.
